After pushing this, I found @hachikuji's WIP branch that does something similar:

https://github.com/confluentinc/kafka/pull/108/files

The main difference is that his branch doesn't allow the per request timeout to be lower than the default request timeout. Whilst that is good enough for the join request case, the more flexible approach in this PR should allow the AdminClient to rely on this functionality instead of implementing it itself.

cc @cmccabe @dguy @guozhangwang @enothereska

Could reproduce locally by increasing the commit interval. A larger commit interval avoids a commit and flush before we inject the error. If we don't commit, we will reprocess the first records after the failure got injected and end up with `<a,12125>` instead of `<a,125>` -- if the commit (that is 100ms for this test) happens before we inject the error, we don't reprocess and the test passed.

Call for review @enothereska @dguy @guozhangwang
LGTM.
Retest this please.

@junrao Finally I was able to fix the test failure by closing the newly added LogDirFailureHandler thread, removing newly-added when the ReplicaManager shutdown, and optimizing the `LogManager.liveLogDirs` not to instantiate new array when there is no offline log dir. These are only causing test failure in Github (not on my machines) probably because the virtual machine used in Github is slower with less memory.

The patch is fully ready for review again :)

@guozhangwang, good point about updating the ConsumerConfig docs. I think I won't mention that it can be overridden, but I'll make the special case clear. Regarding lowering the default, I thought we should do that in a separate PR. I see this as the bug fix (we can probably cherry-pick it to 0.11.0) where lowering the timeout has compatibility implications and may need a bit more discussion.

I agree, that we only want to get if the state is queryable. But I don't think that the change would make the test simpler -- with the change you have to reason about three different cases within `Reduce` (it's additional mental effort to understand that the second case is to avoid duplicate processing -- quite tricky logic). If we know that there are a fixed and small number of possible outcomes, it seems to be straight forward to test for all of them.

Tying wait time to commit interval might be flaky again -- it's always risky to just wait... I would rather not do this to have strong guarantee that a race condition is avoided.

WDYT?
